title: Flemming Lund
text:
Flemming Lund (born 6 October 1952) is a former <a href="Denmark">Danish</a> professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player in the <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a> position, who played both in <a href="Europe">Europe</a> and the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. He played for <a href="Royal%20Antwerp">Royal Antwerp</a> in <a href="Belgium">Belgium</a> and <a href="Germany">German</a> teams <a href="Rot-Weiss%20Essen">Rot-Weiss Essen</a> and <a href="Fortuna%20D%C3%BCsseldorf">Fortuna Düsseldorf</a>, winning the 1979 <a href="DFB-Pokal">DFB-Pokal</a> trophy with Düsseldorf. Lund played 20 games and scored two goals for the <a href="Denmark%20national%20football%20team">Denmark national football team</a> from 1972 to 1979. He moved to the United States in 1979 and played for a number of American teams in the <a href="North%20American%20Soccer%20League%20%281968%E2%80%931984%29">North American Soccer League</a> and the <a href="Major%20Soccer%20League">Major Indoor Soccer League</a>.
European career.
Born in <a href="Copenhagen">Copenhagen</a>, Lund started his career with local top-flight club <a href="B%201903">B 1903</a>. He was called up for the <a href="Denmark%20national%20under-19%20football%20team">Danish national under-19 team</a> in September 1969, and went on to play seven games and score one goal for the under-19 national team until June 1971. He played six games for the <a href="Denmark%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Danish national under-21 team</a> between June 1972 and May 1974. Simultaneously, he debuted for the senior <a href="Denmark%20national%20football%20team">Denmark national team</a> in June 1972 and went on to play 20 games and score two goals for his country until May 1979.
In the summer of 1972, Lund moved abroad to play professionally with <a href="Belgium">Belgian</a> club <a href="Royal%20Antwerp">Royal Antwerp</a>. He made his Antwerp debut in August 1972, and went on to play 124 games and score 20 goals for Antwerp in the <a href="Belgian%20First%20Division">Belgian First Division</a>. After four seasons with Antwerp, Lund went to <a href="Rot-Weiss%20Essen">Rot-Weiss Essen</a> in the German <a href="Bundesliga">Bundesliga</a> championship in 1976. Lund played 34 games and scored two goals for Essen in the <a href="1976%E2%80%9377%20Bundesliga">1976–77 Bundesliga</a> season, but could not prevent Essen from being relegated to the <a href="2.%20Bundesliga">2. Bundesliga</a> at the end of the season. Lund left Essen and moved to Bundesliga club <a href="Fortuna%20D%C3%BCsseldorf">Fortuna Düsseldorf</a>. He played two seasons at Düsseldorf, and won the 1979 <a href="DFB-Pokal">DFB-Pokal</a> trophy with the team. After 62 games and five goals for Düsseldorf in the Bundesliga, Lund left the club in the summer 1979.
American career.
In 1979, Lund signed with the <a href="Dallas%20Tornado">Dallas Tornado</a> of the <a href="North%20American%20Soccer%20League%20%281968%E2%80%931984%29">North American Soccer League</a>. He would remain with Dallas through three outdoor seasons. In the fall of 1979, he joined the <a href="Detroit%20Lightning">Detroit Lightning</a> of the <a href="Major%20Soccer%20League">Major Indoor Soccer League</a> and was named a first team All Star. He then played the 1980–81 indoor season with the Tornado. He returned to the MISL in the fall of 1981 with the <a href="Buffalo%20Stallions">Buffalo Stallions</a>. In 1983, he joined the <a href="Vancouver%20Whitecaps%20%28NASL%29">Vancouver Whitecaps</a>. Seven games into the 1983 season, the Whitecaps sent Lund to the <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Rowdies%20%281975%E2%80%931993%29">Tampa Bay Rowdies</a>. He finished the season in Tampa Bay, then played the 1983–84 NASL indoor season with them. On 27 April 1984, the Rowdies released Lund. In October 1985, he joined the <a href="Cleveland%20Force%20%281978%E2%80%931988%29">Cleveland Force</a> for the 1984–85 MISL season. In February 1985, the Force sent Lund to the <a href="New%20York%20Cosmos%20%281971%E2%80%931985%29">New York Cosmos</a> in exchange for a second-round draft pick. In March, the Cosmos released Lund who then signed with the <a href="Wichita%20Wings">Wichita Wings</a>.
Personal.
He is the father of international <a href="Equestrianism">equestrian</a> <a href="Tina%20Lund">Tina Lund</a>. He has won the <a href="Zealand%20%28Denmark%29">Zealand</a> championship in <a href="badminton">badminton</a> with world champion <a href="Lene%20K%C3%B8ppen">Lene Køppen</a> as his mixed-double partner.
